title: 106_hr2031
content:
The "Twenty-First Amendment Enforcement Act" is cited as the short title. The Act addresses the shipment of intoxicating liquor into a state in violation of state law, amending the Webb-Kenyon Act to include injunctive relief in federal district court. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like 'attorney general', 'intoxicating liquor', 'person', and 'State'. The attorney general or chief law enforcement officer of a State can take action regarding the shipment of intoxicating liquor in violation of state law. The attorney general can take civil action against a person violating state laws on importing or transporting alcohol to enforce compliance and restrain further violations. Federal courts have jurisdiction over such actions. The attorney general can take civil action against individuals violating state laws on alcohol importation or transportation. The court may issue an injunction or order to restrain violations with clear evidence required. The attorney general can seek civil action against those breaking state laws on alcohol importation or transportation. To obtain a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction, evidence of probable irreparable harm and likelihood of success on the merits is necessary. Any injunction issued must provide reasons for its issuance and be specific in its terms, with notice and a hearing required for the adverse party. A temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction must be specific in its terms and describe the act sought to be restrained in detail. The order is binding on the parties involved and those in active concert with them. Any remedy under this section is in addition to other remedies provided by law. State court proceedings are not prohibited by this section, allowing authorized State officials to take action in State court for alleged violations of State laws. "SEC. 3. GENERAL PROVISIONS." The Act does not affect the Internet Tax Freedom Act or the enforcement of the Twenty-First Amendment. It aims to support interstate commerce and prevent unconstitutional discrimination against out-of-state sellers. The Act does not allow state regulation or taxation of Internet services or interstate telecommunications services. It also prohibits injunctions against interactive computer services or electronic communication services used for activities covered by the Act. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF AMENDMENT.

(a) Effective Date.--This Act and its amendment take effect on the enactment date, except as provided in subsection (b).

(b) Application of Amendment.--The amendment applies to importation or transportation of intoxicating liquor after specific dates based on the enactment date of the Act.

SEC. 4. STUDY. The Attorney General is required to conduct a study to determine the impact of the Act and submit the results to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment.
